name: 4-H Dog Obedience Classes
description:
4-H Dog Obedience Classes will be held at Vince's Park starting in April. Classes will be held from 6 pm to 8 pm on Monday evenings.  The series of classes will run Monday, April 29th to Monday, June 24th. *Please note the first class will be without the dogs*


Youth ages 5 to 18 years of age may participate, youth ages 5 to 7 need an adult on the leash with them at all times.


Dogs should be 4 months of age or older.  Youth must provide a copy of their dogâ€™s current Rabies Certificate to the 4-H Office to keep on file. They must also carry a copy of their Rabies Certificate to each class and event they attend with their dog.


Purebreed and mixed breed dogs are both welcome. Dogs showing any signs of aggressive tendencies will be excused from class.


Space is limited. Registration is required. RSVP by Friday, April 23rd


Fee for the classes:  Free for current 4-H members. $15 for non-members (includes a 1 year membership in 4-H)


For additional information, please contact 4-H Youth Development Educator, Nate Kennedy at 315-539-9251 or nk623@cornell.edu.



Registration for event has CLOSED.

name: 4-H Forestry Training (4/29/19)
description:
The Youth Forestry Training Workshop is designed to prepare youth for the NYS Forestry Weekend in May.  Youth will build skills in tree ID, measurement, pests, etc.   The workshop will take place in the Siuslaw Model Forest, Acra.

name: April is Sustainability Month at Cornell
description:
Cornell University celebrates all things sustainability during the entire month of April, with 60+ events in film, fashion, art, wellness, social justice, climate change leadership, and sustainability topics.  

Anyone can host an event!  See the Sustainable Campus website for helpful tips on how to participate, and sign up for the Sustainability Listserv to stay in the know about the latest new opportunities added during April. 

View all Sustainability Month events in the Cornell Events calendar or check out a highlight of key events below.

KEY EVENTS

Climate Change Seminar Series 
Mondays at 2:55pm, 233 Plant Science Building or via Webinar

  • 4/8: Climate Change, Indigenous Communities, and the Imperative for Action!
  • 4/15: Our Changing Menu: What Climate Change Means to the Foods We Love and Need
  • 4/22: Building Climate Resilience for Greater US Security
  • 4/29: What Is the Social Cost of Carbon?

Advance Your Skills - Cornell Sustainability Management Academy Training (Registration req)

  • 4/3, 9am-Noon: Sustainability 101 (Staff Training)
  • 4/4 1pm-4pm: Sustainability 201 (Staff Training)

Fairs, Festivals

  • 4/8: Dairy Alternative Day
  • 4/10: Cornell Energy Day
  • 4/20-4/27: People’s Climate Week: Events focused on the intersections between climate change and social justice issues through the stories of climate migrants and marginalized communities. 
  • 4/27: Spring Fest

Lectures

  • 4/18: Sustainable and Just Food Systems Ideas to Action Forum
  • Finance and Sustainability Series: A weekly lecture series that highlights leaders in the sustainable global enterprise industry.
    • 4/9: Dr. Laurie Marker, Founder and Executive Director of the Cheetah Conservation Fund (CCF)
    • 4/16: Linda C. Giuliano, Head of Responsible Investment for AllianceBernstein
    • 4/23: Niki Armacost, Managing Director of Arc Finance

Films, Art & Fashion

  • 4/1 - 4/7: Finger Lakes Environmental Film Festival (FLEFF)
  • 4/1-4/30: ReGeneration: Human Ecology Building Art Exhibit
  • 4/16: "Smartfin" Film and Talk with Todd McGrain
  • 4/16: Ecosystem Benefits of Campus Trees
  • 4/17: A new approach for functional textiles and protective clothing

Social & Environmental Justice

  • 4/8: Dairy Alternative Day
  • 4/8: Should We All Be Vegan?
  • 4/11: Grassroots to Global: Broader Impacts of Civic Ecology
  • 4/20-4/27: People's Climate Week
    Full week of activities including an arts quad camp out and fund-raiser, labor and climate organizing teach-in, green-up day, and more!

Sustainability Challenges

  • 4/19-4/26: Cornell Carpool Challenge
  • 4/21: Spring into Sustainability
    Join the Cornell Sustainability Consultants, Cornell ECO, and Spark Design for a sustainability focused case competition.

 

Content promotion and events coordination support provided by:

  • The Campus Sustainability Office
  • Atkinson Center for a Sustainable Future

name: Art Exhibit: "Traces" by Emma Ulen-Klees
description: Traces by Emma Ulen-Klees represents the beginning of an on-going project, which seeks to catalog vulnerable plant taxa within the state of New York. Seven species displayed represent a small percentage of plants that are either extirpated (SX) or considered endangered historical species (SH), not having been recorded in 20-30 years. Each piece was researched and based on a particular specimen within the collections of the Liberty Hyde Bailey Herbarium at Cornell, or the C. V. Starr Virtual Herbarium. These embossings serve as a personal homage to the absence of an increasing number of this region's flora from their botanic communities.

name: Mandatory Arbitration Roundtable, Ithaca NY
description:
Join CIHLER for a roundtable co-hosted by Interim Dean of the ILR School Alexander Colvin and Professor Dave Sherwyn.

Discussion topics include:

Mandatory Arbitration and Class Action Waivers:

1) The arguments for and against

2) Personal experiences - management and employees

3) What will employees do / how will employers react?

name: Better Process Control School
description:
New York State Food Venture Center, Department of Food Science - Cornell University, Cornell Cooperative Extension, GMA Science and Education Foundation, Associated New York State Food Processors, Inc., NYS Department of Agriculture and Markets.

The Better Process Control Schools (BPCS) certify supervisors of thermal processing systems, acidification, and container closure evaluation programs for low-acid and acidified canned foods. Each processor of low-acid or acidified foods must operate with a certified supervisor on hand at all times during processing.

name: PolliNation: Artists & Scientists Crossing Borders to Explore the Value of Pollinator Health
description:
Threats to pollinator health are intense and varied, from habitat loss and climate change to diseases and pesticides. A new exhibit at Mann Library showcases the results of a multi-year collaboration between the lab of Cornell entomology professor Scott McArt and Welsh artists, who cross national and disciplinary boundaries to celebrate the beauty and importance of pollinators, and reveal how their fate is linked to our planet, and to our own.

Originally developed as a pioneering Arts and Humanities Research Council funded Networking project in Wales called Cross-Pollination: Revaluing Pollinators through Arts and Science Collaboration, this project has brought artists and scientists together on two continents to explore and promote the world-wide crisis facing pollinators. Cross-Pollination was led by the University of Wales Trinity Saint David in partnership with Aberystwyth University and the National Botanic Garden of Wales. Additional funding was provided by the Arts Council of Wales to enhance the art-work production and to increase the impact of the project, and Wales Arts International to help fund the exhibit in Mann Library.
